text.0: that gift of ours which indra loves and welcomes even that he makes for us the great and strong one.
text.1: he who comes wielding in his might the thunder maghavan gives prayer praise and laud and soma.
text.2: bull hurler of the fouredged rainproducer with both his arms strong mighty most heroic.
text.3: wearing as wool paruṣṇī for adornment whose joints for sake of friendship he hath covered.
text.4: god who of all the gods was born divinest endowed with ample strength and mighty powers.
text.5: and bearing in his arms the yearning thunder with violent rush caused heaven and earth to tremble.
text.6: before the high god at his birth heaven trembled earth many floods and all the precipices.
text.7: the strong one bringeth nigh the bulls two parents loud sing the winds like men in airs midregion.
text.8: these are thy great deeds indra thine the mighty deeds to be told aloud at all libations.
text.9: that thou o hero bold and boldly daring didst with thy bolt by strength destroy the dragon.
text.10: true are all these thy deeds o most heroic the milchkine issued from the streaming udder.
text.11: in fear of thee o thou of manly spirit the rivers swiftly set themselves in motion.
text.12: with joy o indra lord of tawny coursers the sisters then these goddesses extolled thee.
text.13: when thou didst give the prisoned ones their freedom to wander at their will in long succession.
text.14: pressed is the gladdening stalk as twere a river so let the rite the toilers power attract thee.
text.15: to usward of the bright one as the courser strains his exceedingly strong leather bridle.
text.16: ever by us perform thy most heroic thine highest best victorious deeds o victor.
text.17: for us make vṛtras easy to be conquered destroy the weapon of our mortal foeman.
text.18: graciously listen to our prayer o indra and strength of varied sort bestow thou on us.
text.19: send to us all intelligence arid wisdom o maghavan be he who gives us cattle.
text.20: now indra lauded glorified with praises let wealth swell high like rivers to the singer.
text.21: for thee a new hymn lord of bays is fashioned may we carborne through song be victors ever.
